poor  sanitation;  part  B,  drainage  and  flood  protection;  part  C,

Thanh Hoa, and the district-level town of Lang Co. Part D will also 
include  Chan  May  urban  area,  Phu  Loc  district  town,  and  four 
communes in Phu Loc District of Thua Thien Hue Province. 
 
The total project cost, including physical and price contingencies, 
duties,  taxes,  and  interest  during  construction,  is  estimated  at 
$96.0  million  equivalent.  The  foreign  exchange  cost  is  $53.6 
million  equivalent,  or  55.8%  of  total.  The  local  currency  cost, 
including duties and taxes, is $42.4 million equivalent, or 44.2% of 
total. 
 
It is proposed that ADB provides a loan of $44.0 million equivalent 
from  its  Special  Funds  resources  to  cover  45.8%  of  the  total 
project  cost.  The  ADB  loan  will  have  a  maturity  of  32  years, 
including a grace period of 8 years. It will carry an interest rate of 
1%  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  thereafter. The French aid 
agency, Agence Française de Développement (AFD), will provide 
a  loan  of  30  million  euros  ($31.8  million  equivalent)  for  joint

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

3. 
Viet  Nam’s  population  in  2003  is  almost  80  million,  about  20  million  in  urban  areas. 
Urbanization  has  increased  markedly—from  20%  in  1990  to  about  25%  in  2003—and  the 
Government estimates that about 45% of the population will live in urban areas by 2020. Lack of 
sufficient land, capital investment, and employment opportunities in rural areas and towns in the 
central region  over  the  past  decade  have  fuelled  migration  to  Hanoi  and  Ho  Chi  Minh  City 
(HCMC).  The  population  of  the  two  major  cities  increased  about  1.5  times  over  the  past  10 
years,  and  now  accounts  for  almost  40%  of  the  country’s  total  urban  population.  Hanoi  and 
HCMC have attracted most foreign investment and assistance, adding to the attraction for rural 
migrants  to  these  cities  and  harming  balanced  urban  and  regional  development.  Furthermore, 
rapid  migration  to  the  two  major  cities  has  caused  deterioration  of  the  urban  environment, 
exacerbation of urban poverty, and worsening urban unemployment.  
 
4. 
Despite substantial migration away from the central region over the past 10 years, that 
area’s  urban  population  continues  growing  at  an  average  of  4.7%  a  year.  In  1999,  cities 
accounted  for  20.6%  of  total  population  in  the  region  compared  to  17.5%  10  years  earlier. 
During  the  last  decade,  the  urban  population  of  the  region  rose  56%  to  4.5  million,  compared 
with a national increase of 43%. Population in project towns has grown quickly and ranges from 
57,000 in Ha Tinh to 186,000 in Thanh Hoa, while the district town of Lang Co has about 11,000 
permanent  residents.  Urban  poverty  levels  in  the  project  towns  are  higher  than  the  national 
average urban poverty level, ranging from 13.5% to 19.2%.  
 
Urban  infrastructure  in  the  six  project  towns  is  unable  to  meet  the  growing  demand

40% of households in provincial towns and 10% in the district town have septic tanks, only a few 
are connected to sewers or drains. Composting latrines and defecation in open areas are used 
instead. They create major health risks, particularly during floods.  Solid waste is collected from

7. 
The Government selected the project towns based on a comparative analysis of towns in 
the 18 provinces in the central region. Selection criteria included (i) urban population growth, (ii) 
urban  and  rural  poverty  levels,  (iii)  economic  development  potential,  and  (iv) infrastructure 
needs.  The  district  town  of  Lang  Co  was  selected  as  a  pilot  case  for  sustainable  urban 
environmental  management  in  a  very  small  town  because  of  its  tourism  potential.  The  five 
provincial capitals act as administrative and economic centers for their surrounding rural areas, 
and provide most of the nonagricultural employment in their provinces.   
 
8. 
Since the mid-1980s, external funding agencies have provided loans of more than $700 
million for developing drainage, sanitation, and solid waste projects in Viet Nam. Approximately 
65% of this amount has financed environmental improvement projects in HCMC ($308 million) 
and Hanoi ($156 million). In provincial towns, external assistance has focused on water supply 
systems, but investment in drainage, sanitation, and solid waste improvements in the towns has 
been  relatively  small,  particularly  in  the  central  region.  Detailed  information  on  external 
assistance to Viet Nam’s urban sector is presented in Appendix 2. 
 
B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

9. 
The  key  problems  of  the  urban  sector  in  Viet  Nam  include  (i)  inadequate  capital 
investment  in  drainage,  wastewater,  sanitation,  and  solid  waste  systems;  (ii)  lack  of  central 
government  guidance  for  urban  management,  slow  implementation  of  policy  reforms  at  the 
provincial  level,  and  an  incomplete  legal  framework;  (iii)  weak  and  unaccountable  urban 
institutions  and  poorly  defined  institutional  arrangements;  (iv)  inadequate  cost  recovery 
mechanisms  to  obtain  sufficient  financial  resources  for  proper  operation  and  maintenance 
(O&M);  (v)  insufficient  technical  and  managerial  human  resources  capacity  in  urban 
management  and  services  agencies;  and  (vi)  poor  community  awareness  and  participation  in 
planning  and  management  of  urban  services,  particularly  for  women.  A  detailed  urban  sector 
analysis is presented in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
10. 
Since  1990,  the  Government  has  introduced  policies  and  reforms  to  improve  the 
efficiency  of  the  urban  sector  and  promote  urban  development.  The  Comprehensive  Poverty 
Reduction  and  Growth  Strategy  2001–2010  mentions  several  objectives  relevant  to  the  urban 
sector, including  (i)  promoting  balanced  and  sustainable  economic  growth  between  regions;

(ii) developing urban areas to create more jobs and improve living standards;4 (iii) strengthening 
environment protection and ensuring a healthy environment;5  (iv) promoting gender equity and 
enhancing  the  participation  of  women  at  all  levels  of  leadership;  (v) implementing  fully  the 
decree on democracy at the grassroots level to improve people’s participation in local economic 
development; and (vi) strengthening accountability at all levels, especially local governments, by 
improving transparency of and publicity for local budgets. 
  
11. 
The Government’s policies for urban development are presented in the Orientation Plan 
for  Urban  Development  to  2020.  The  orientation  plan’s  objective  is  to  progressively  provide 
urban areas with appropriate modern infrastructure and a healthy environment to allow them to 
actively contribute to the country’s socioeconomic development. The policy gives emphasis to (i) 
developing  urban  centers  as  economic  growth  centers,  (ii)  developing  and  modernizing 
technical  and  social  infrastructure  to  attract  investment  and  improve  living  standards,  (iii) 
reducing  gaps  in  economic  development  and  living  standards  between  urban  and  rural  areas, 
and  (iv)  ensuring  sustainable  urban  development  by  taking  account  of  environmental  factors 
and efficient use of natural resources. The plan recognizes the need to strengthen and improve 
the efficiency of urban management systems and policies.  
 
The  Government’s  development  targets  and  policies  for  drainage  and  sanitation,

latrines in urban areas by 2005, (iv) provide waste collection systems that treat solid and liquid 
wastes,  and  (v)  gradually  rehabilitate  and  clean  the  canal  systems.  To  achieve  these

development planning, sector policy formulation, regulations, training, and technology transfer, 
and  terminating  its  direct  involvement  in  business  activities;  (ii)  clearly  defining  the  roles  and 
responsibilities of various Government agencies involved in the water and sanitation sector and 
encouraging  better  cooperation  among  these  sector  agencies;  (iii)  making  provincial  people’s 
committees  (PPCs)  the  responsible  agencies  for  water  supply,  sanitation,  and  drainage

implementation  and  O&M  encouraging  service  providers  to  become  self-financing  and

particularly on drainage and sanitation issues; (vii) mobilizing additional financial resources; (viii)

In June 1999, MOC issued guidelines for setting water supply and drainage tariffs. PPCs 
still  hold  authority  to  set  tariffs,  but  the  guidelines  provide  a  framework  and  methodology  for 
them to use in establishing these tariffs. A drainage charge is to be no lower than 10% of the 
total water production cost. However, the guidelines give no timeframe for applying the drainage 
charge. As a result, only a few provinces apply drainage and wastewater charges. At present, 
drainage charges are levied in only one of the six project towns: Tam Ky. However, even there 
the  fees  the  PPC  collects  are  not  used  for  O&M  for  drainage  and  sewerage.  For  solid  waste 
management, tariffs are set at levels that do not allow sufficient funds to be collected for proper 
O&M.  Although  the  Government  has  introduced  policies  and  reforms  to  improve  the  financial 
autonomy and sustainability of urban service providers—increasing cost-recovery through user 
charges and gradually eliminating central Government subsidies—existing policies have yet to 
be fully implemented at the provincial level. 
 
15. 
Town  people’s  committees  (TPCs)  are  responsible  for  administration  in  provincial  and 
district towns. Most TPCs have established urban management divisions, but they lack capacity 
to perform because of scarce human resources. In many cases there is confusion between the 
role of the TPCs and the role of the departments of construction at the PPCs. TPCs do not have 
the  mandate  or  capacity  to  fix  or  assign  performance  standards  to  urban  environmental 
companies  (URENCOs)  or  to  monitor  their  performance.  Poor  performance  by  the  URENCOs 
and TPCs results in a general lack of trust from citizens and a reluctance to pay service fees. 
 
16.

urban  centers  and  transform  them  into  sources  of  economic  growth  and  employment.  The

capital investment in urban areas of high government priority; (ii) supporting the preparation of 
national guidelines on urban management and facilitating the implementation of national policies 
at the provincial level; (iii) improving urban institutions capabilities and institutional framework for 
urban  environmental  management;  (iv)  establishing

capacities of URENCOs and TPCs, and (vi) increasing community awareness and participation,

 17. 
Lessons Learned. Some major lessons have been learned through implementing water 
supply  and  sanitation  projects  in  Viet  Nam  and  ADB  urban-sector  interventions  in  other 
countries. One key lesson is that  projects often face delays in establishing project management 
units  (PMU),  selecting  consultants,  acquiring  land,  resettling  people,  awarding contracts, and 
making  disbursements.  These  delays  have  increased  project  costs  and  frustrated  both 
beneficiaries  and  local  authorities.  There  is  a  need  for  (i)  greater  delegation  of  authority  to 
lower-level government agencies for implementation, with central Government ministries acting 
as  facilitators;  (ii) intensive  assistance  to  the  executing  agencies  in  project  planning  and 
management  early  during  implementation;  (iii)  advance  action  for  recruiting  consultants;  (iv) 
establishment of PMUs during project preparation; and (v) timely preparation for land acquisition 
and  resettlement.  Early  and  systematic  training  in  Government  and  ADB  procedures  for  all 
project  stakeholders—including  provincial  agencies,  consultants,  counterpart  staff,  and 
representatives of community groups—will be essential to minimize delays. 
 
18. 
Previous projects yield further lessons that have been incorporated in the Project. Community-
based activities and public health awareness programs have not been optimized in previous projects 
because PMUs were reluctant to allocate funds, coordination was lacking among local institutions,

Part B: Drainage and Flood Protection 

Part  B  includes  (i)  drainage  improvement,  and  (ii)  flood  protection  improvement. 
26. 
Drainage improvement will include improving flood regulating basins, rehabilitating and cleaning 
55  kilometers  (km)  of  existing  drains,  building  or  upgrading  60  km  of  primary  drains, 
constructing 175 km of secondary drains, and building 138 km of tertiary drains to convey storm

routes, and will consist of box culverts in densely populated areas, or open channels with raised 
embankments  in  low-density  areas.  Flood  protection  improvement  will  include  building  dikes 
and  roads,  3.0  km  and  2.8  km  long  respectively,  in  Tam  Ky  and  Dong  Ha  towns  to  protect 
riverside communities from frequent river flooding.

Part C: Wastewater and Public Sanitation 

27. 
Part C includes (i) wastewater improvement, and (ii) public sanitation. The wastewater 
component is designed to collect, treat, and safely dispose of wastewater from the urban areas

Co,  it  will  develop  a  separate  sewerage  system,  comprising  28  km  of  sewers,  3  sewage-

a 1-km access road with an asphalt surface. The public sanitation component aims to improve 
public health and reduce pollution in the streets, canals, waterways, and lakes in project towns. 
For each town, it will introduce a septic tank management system; improve sanitation facilities in 
public areas such as markets, schools, bus stations, cultural centers, parks, and health clinics; 
and supply O&M equipment for sanitation.

Special Features 

31. 
Poverty.  The  Project  has  been  classified  as  a  poverty  intervention  strategy,  and  will 
contribute  to  achieving  the  objectives  of  the  Comprehensive  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth 
Strategy 2001–2010. The urban poor in project towns live in underserved areas where drainage 
is dysfunctional or nonexistent, flooding is frequent, access to solid waste collection is limited, 
sanitation is inadequate, and the environment is polluted because of poor toilet and septic tank 
facilities.  About  21.2%  of  project  beneficiaries  are  poor.  Poverty  rates  in  the  six  project  towns 
are higher than the national urban average of 11.1% while poverty levels in the rural area of Phu 
Loc  district  is  higher  than  the  national  average.  About  16.3%  of  the  urban  population  in  the 
project towns and about 40% of the residents in  Chan May town and Phu Loc district are poor. 
The  Project  will  develop  and  expand  urban  services  to  poor  and  low-income  households, 
generate  new  employment  opportunities,  develop  community  ownership  and  self-reliance, 
reduce  the  risk  of  disease  through  health  awareness  programs,  and  ensure  a  sustainable 
environment.  The Project  will  directly  address  one  of  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  and 
Targets  (MDGTs)  referring  to  sanitation  improvements,  and will  contribute  to  achieving  other 
MDGTs  by  improving  health  of  the  local  population  and  reducing  poverty  and  vulnerability.  A 
summary poverty reduction and social strategy is presented in Appendix 4. A poverty and social 
analysis is presented in Supplementary Appendix C. 
 
Gender. The issue of gender has received special attention during project preparation.

Community Participation.  All project components were formulated after discussions with 
concerned government officials and consultations with affected communities and beneficiaries. The 
Project is designed so that it is responsive to the communities' needs, will function on a sustainable 
basis, and will have no adverse social or environmental impacts. The Project will promote grassroots 
participation  in  urban  infrastructure  planning  and  environmental  improvements  by  providing 
community groups with (i) adequate information about community and household sanitation programs; 
(ii) sufficient opportunities to participate during project preparation, implementation, maintenance, and 
operations; and (iii) concerted capacity building for poor and low -income communities in developing

groups and individual households to set their own priorities for urban environmental improvements, 
and to utilize and manage sanitation and solid waste subcomponents based on collective resources 
and contributions. Results of participation with affected people illustrate different community dynamics 
and reactions to resettlement as reflected in resettlement plans. Consultation with local communities 
on environmental issues has been incorporated into the IEEs and EMP.  
 
39. 
Strengthening  of  Urban  Policies  and  Institutions.  The  Project  will  improve  the 
efficiency and sustainability of urban services in project towns by improving the institutional and 
operational framework for urban management and delivery of urban environmental services. At 
the national level, the Project will support MOC to prepare guidelines on urban management, as 
well as guidelines on drainage, sanitation, and solid waste tariffs.  At the town level, the Project 
will  support  the  urban  management  divisions  of  the  TPCs  to  improve  their  capacities  in  urban 
planning and management, and to become efficient units able to monitor the quality and level of 
services delivered by URENCOs and other public or private service providers. 
 
40. 
The Project will support the transformation of URENCOs into autonomous and efficient 
companies, accountable to the TPCs and their clients. The Project will promote institutional and 
legal reforms at the provincial level and provide technical support to URENCOs to allow them to 
(i)  establish  accounting  systems  and  separate  budgets  and  accounts  following  Vietnamese 
Accounting Standards for each of their main activities, distinguishing between (a) drainage and 
wastewater,  (b)  solid  waste  management,  (c)  other  O&M  activities,  and  (d)  new  construction 
activities; (ii) change the focus of URENCOs to management and O&M of urban infrastructure 
by  progressively  separating  construction  units;  (iii)  calculate,  recommend,  and 
justify 
appropriate fees for drainage, wastewater, and solid waste to clients and people’s councils, and 
agree on appropriate service levels with TPCs; (iv) own equipment for O&M and keep sufficient 
funds  for  depreciation  of  equipment  and  repayment  of  loans;  (v) collect  drainage  and  solid 
waste fees, retaining all revenues in two separate accounts and using them solely for O&M of 
the solid waste and drainage and wastewater facilities, respectively, under the responsibility of a 
URENCO;  (vi)  impose  penalties  on  people  who  do  not  pay  for  services  received,  or  destroy 
urban  infrastructure  under  their  responsibility; (vii)  adopt  and  implement  efficient  and  effective 
asset management procedures; (viii) prepare and adopt O&M plans, manuals, and procedures; 
and (ix) implement efficient financial and management information systems.

support  Government  policy  by  helping  URENCOs  generate  more  revenue  from  their  own 
sources,  and  gradually  reduce  Government  subsidies.  Tariffs  will  be  increased  so  that 
URENCOs  can  collect  enough  resources  to  pay  all  O&M  costs  and  depreciation  of  O&M 
equipment for drainage, wastewater, and solid waste management. Recommended tariffs have 
been calculated so they are affordable to low-income and poor people. Water supply companies 
in  each  province  will  collect  charges  for  drainage  and  wastewater  services  on  behalf  of the

The  Project  will  directly  benefit  a  total  of  504,000  people  in  the  six  project  towns,  of 
which  50%  are  women.  Rural  population  in  the  areas  around  these  towns  will  also  indirectly 
benefit.  Reduced  migration  to  Hanoi  and  HCMC  because  of  improved  quality  of  life  in  the 
project  area  will  reduce  pressure  on  Hanoi’s  and  HCMC’s  urban  systems.  Improvements  to 
urban  environmental  infrastructure  will  bring  about  increased  social  benefits  to  local  residents 
and  communities  and  to  the  urban  development  sector  in  general.  Inadequate  infrastructure 
systems  pose  serious  environmental  and  health  risks,  and  inhibit  social  and  economic 
development.  The  Project  will  aim  to  reduce  environment-related  diseases,  lower  medical 
expenses, and lessen the impact of flooding on household incomes from lost working days and 
household  damages.  For  the  poor  and  low-income communities, the impact will be the most 
visible.  Many  reside  in  low-lying,  flood-prone  areas  where  improving  drainage,  sanitation,  and 
solid waste systems are pivotal to improved health and hygiene.  
 
Other social and gender  benefits include increased community participation by the poor 
61. 
and  women  and  enhanced  self-reliance  in  urban  environmental  management.  Women  are 
responsible for a variety of tasks relating to sanitation at both the family and community levels, 
especially  as  sweepers  and  waste  collectors  employed  by  a  URENCO.  Increasing  the  role  of 
women  in  urban  management  and  institutions  will  (i)  improve  sanitation  and  public  health 
practices,  and  (ii)  strengthen  the  capacity  of  women  to  hold  managerial  positions  and  take 
ownership for small-scale urban environmental improvements within their communities. Through 
demand-based  interventions,  upgrading  a  small  fishing  village  in  Lang  Co  will  have  significant 
social and economic benefits, including the potential to participate in the tourism industry.

B.  

Economic Benefits 

62. 
The  economic  analysis  has  been  undertaken  following  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  the 
Economic  Analysis  of  Projects  (1997) and ADB’s  Framework  for  the  Economic  and  Financial 
Appraisal  of  Urban  Development  Sector  Projects  (1994).  The  analysis  comprises  least-cost 
analyses  of  alternative  options  for  all  project  components  and  a  cost-benefit  analysis  for  the 
drainage component in each town.  The major economic benefits arise from reduced incidence 
and  severity  of  flooding.  These  have  been  quantified  in  terms  of  resource  cost  savings  from 
avoided  (i)  damage  to  property;  (ii)  cleanup  costs  after  flooding;  (iii)  time  lost  due  to  travel 
delays;  (iv)  lost  employment  opportunities;  (v) loss of business income; (vi)  medical costs and 
public  health  expenditure  related  to  waterborne  diseases;  and  (vii)  expenditure  on  the 
maintenance  for  roads,  drains,  and  other  municipal  infrastructure  damaged  by  floods. 
Nonquantifiable  benefits  include  reduced  threat  of  disruption  to  social  activities  and  stress 
caused by such events to the urban communities. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) 
calculated  for  each  town  ranges  from  16.4%  to  21.1%.  The  sensitivities  of  the  EIRRs  of  the 
drainage and flood protection components are tested against adverse changes in key variables. 
The  result  of  sensitivity  analysis  shows  that  the  Project  is  most  sensitive  to  delays  in  project 
completion. However, all EIRRs exceed 12%. The economic analysis is presented in Appendix 
13; details are available in Supplementary Appendix L.   
 
C. 

Financial Aspects 

63. 
Financial  analyses  were  conducted  to  determine  the  financial  viability  of  the  selected 
components and the sustainability of the six URENCOs. In addition, a financial internal rate of 
return (FIRR) is calculated for the solid waste management component in each town. For the 
drainage  and  flood  protection  component,  the  Project  aims  to  directly  recover,  via  water  tariff 
surcharge,  the  full  O&M  cost,  including  the  capital  cost  of  the  equipment for O&M purposes. 
Additionally,  an  environmental  fee  or  a  surcharge  on  the  land  and  house  tax  will  be  levied  by 
each TPC or PPC to recover an appropriate portion of capital costs.8 In 2004, all project towns 
will  implement  a  10%  surcharge  on  the  water  bill,  increase  it  to  20%  in  2006,  and  increase  it 
further to the level required for recovering the full O&M cost of the services in 2007.  
 
For  solid  waste  management  systems,  the  Project  aims  for  full  cost  recovery.9  To 
64. 
achieve this target, all project towns will apply a differentiated user fee for domestic, commercial 
and  institutional,  and  industrial  users  starting  from  2007.  All  project  towns  will  increase  the 
current solid waste user fee by 30% in 2004 and further 20% in 2006. The FIRRs calculated for 
the  solid  waste  component  range  from  7.2%  to  10.6%,  all  above  the  estimated  weighted 
average cost of capital of 4.0% for the Project.  
 
65. 
Affordability  analyses  have  been  undertaken  to  ensure  that  the  service  users, 
particularly the poor, can afford water surcharges for drainage and wastewater service and user 
fees for solid waste management. These fees were found affordable.  The financial projections 
prepared  for  the  six  URENCOs  indicate  that  financial  performance  improves  over  the  2004–
2014 forecast period as drainage/wastewater tariffs are applied and solid waste tariff increases 
are  implemented.  The  Government’s  budget  support  to  the  services  will  be  gradually  reduced 
and finally eliminated in year 2007. The financial analysis is presented in Appendix 14; details 
are available in Supplementary Appendix M.

social and economic development. This has fueled the rural to urban migration: the population of Hanoi and Ho Chi

The Project will reduce flooding and improve drainage, sanitation, and solid waste systems in five provincial capitals 
and one district level town in the central region. Demand-based community awareness and pro-poor sanitation (APPS) 
programs  will  expand  services  to  poor  and  low-income  households  and  communities  in  remote  and  underserved

Poverty Analysis   

 

Proposed Classification: Poverty Intervention 
Thematic Areas: Human Development 

 
The central region is one of the poorest in Viet Nam. The selected project towns experience levels of poverty where 
the  urban  living  standard  is  poorer  than  the  national  average.  According  to  the  Viet  Nam  Living  Standard  Survey 
(VLSS),  the  national  urban  poverty  average  is  11.1%.  About  21.2%  of  the  total  beneficiaries  from  the  Project  are 
expected  to  be  poor.  This  percentage  includes  the  total  number  of  beneficiaries  from  the  solid  waste  component  in 
Lang Co that live in the Chan May urban area, Phoc Loc district, and four communes of the Phoc Loc district. There 
are  also  some  households  that  reside  just  above  the  poverty  line,  and  are  equally  susceptible  to  shocks,  poor 
sanitation, and floods, all of which weaken their human capital, especially their health. 
 
The  Project  will  directly  address  one  of  the  millennium  development  goals  and  targets  (MDGTs):  to  ensure 
environmental sustainability. This includes reducing the risk of disaster from floods, and further impoverishment from 
poor drainage, sanitation, and solid waste collection.  The  majority  of  the  urban  poor  work  in  unstable  and  low-paid 
jobs,  where  median  household  income  ranges  from  D400,000-800,000  per  month.  The  urban-poor  reside  in 
underserved  areas  where  drainage  is  dysfunctional  or  nonexistent,  access  to  solid  waste  collection  is  limited, 
sanitation is inadequate, and the environment is polluted due to the lack of appropriate toilet and septic tank facilities. 
They  are  up  to  3.5  times  as  likely  to  experience  flooding  of  their  houses  than  nonpoor  households,  and  are  more 
vulnerable to shocks such as sickness due to poor sanitation or flooding. Environmental diseases have high economic 
and  social  consequences,  including  high  medical  expenses  and  lost  working  days  that  harm  incomes  and  further 
marginalize the poor. 
 
The Project will reduce flooding and improve drainage, sanitation, and solid waste systems.  Improvements made in 
environmental  management  further  contribute  to  the  achievement  of  other MDGTs. Improved sanitation and better 
drainage reduces (i) illnesses and mortality amongst different population groups, and (ii) the associated economic and 
social costs. Community-based interventions will expand services to remote and underserved communities, including 
resettlement areas. Poor households will benefit from these improvements, as they cluster in areas that are low-lying 
and  poorly  serviced  by  solid  waste  collectors.  Community  awareness  and  participation  programs  will  educate  and 
inform  beneficiaries  so  that  they  are  active  participants  in  their  own  development.  Community-based sanitation 
programs  will  strengthen  community  ownership  and  management  of  local  environmental  improvements,  and  the 
household sanitation program will increase septic  tank  coverage  amongst  the  poor  and  low-income.  Poor  and  low-
income  households,  especially  those  engaging  in  the  community-based  sanitation  program,  will  make  special 
arrangements with urban environmental companies (URENCOs) to ensure affordable services.

increased  citizen  responsibilities  through  grassroots  participation  in  utilizing  and  managing  infrastructure  projects.

revealed challenges, strategies, and solutions for project design and implementation. Socioeconomic surveys obtained

loss surveys, were  conducted  amongst  resettlement-affected populations. Special consultations were also held with

collaboration of stakeholders. Levels of participation include information exchange, consultation, collaboration, review 
and comments on reports, and empowerment. Weekly meetings, workshops, reviews, consultation meetings, technical 
work groups, and planning groups are the various forms of communications used to ensure active participation, project 
support, and productive feedback. Based on lessons  learned,  a  community  management  committee  in  each  Project 
town  will  be  formed  to  (i)  coordinate  APPS,  (ii)  enhance  community  ownership  at  the  local  level,  and  (iii)  provide 
financial support for community and household sanitation improvements. The community management committee will 
help increase accountability and distribute responsibilities among the Women’s Union, URENCO, and town people’s 
committee in each project town.

16. 
Drain components are designed to reduce flooding, remove storm- and wastewater from

17.

In  general,  connecting  industries  to  public  sewers  is  sensible,  reducing  the  number  of

groundwater  or  downstream  surface  water  resources.  An  integral  part  of  landfill  design  is  the

monitoring system needs to be established to measure effectiveness of mitigation.

Least-Cost Analysis  

Combined Wastewater/Drainage Systems and Flood Protection 

A. 
 
1. 
The economic analysis  has  been  conducted  following  the  ADB’s Guidelines for the 
Economic  Analysis  of  Projects  (1997) and the  Framework for the Economic and Financial 
Appraisal of Urban Development  Sector Projects (1994) to test the economic efficiency and 
viability of the Project. Least-cost analyses were undertaken for drainage, wastewater, and 
public sanitation, and solid waste subprojects. A cost-benefit analysis is carried out for each 
drainage  subproject.  The  subprojects  are  evaluated  over  a  period  of  30  years  with  no 
salvage value assumed thereafter. 
 
B. 
 
Least-cost  analyses  were  carried  out  for  the  three  main  engineering  project 
2. 
components:  (i)  combined  drainage  and  wastewater  systems  and  flood  protection,  (ii) 
wastewater  treatment  in  Lang  Co  and  Thanh  Hoa,  and  (iii)  solid  waste  systems,  with  the 
development of sanitary landfills and upgrading and expansion of collection systems.  
 
 
 
3. 
The drainage subcomponents in the five provincial towns will improve the combined 
drainage systems as a first step toward long-term drainage master plans. Separate drainage 
and  sewerage  systems  will  be  developed  in  Lang  Co,  in  accordance  with  its  master  plan. 
Flood protection improvement will include the construction of dike roads and tide gates.  
 
The  capacity  of  the  combined  drain  depends  primarily  on  the  design  storm14  and 
4. 
catchment  characteristics,  as  wastewater  represent  only  a  small  percentage  of  the  total 
conduit flows in the wet season. Design storm return periods adopted for the project are 2 
years for primary drains and 1-2 years for secondary and tertiary drains, in accordance with 
current  practice  in  Vietnam.  Designing  for  more  severe  events  is  not  justified  because  the 
increased costs outweigh the benefits arising from less frequent flooding.
